Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 14 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Governing_Law: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Application_Facts: Interpreter failed to provide precise, continuous, and competent interpretation; used Lingala and paraphrased; applicant repeatedly stated she could not understand.
Procedural_Issue: Inadequate interpretation affecting fairness of hearing
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of accurate interpretation impacting record and credibility assessment
Credibility_Assessment: Negatively affected due to inability to understand interpreter
Decision_Outcome: Serious breach of procedural fairness found
Remedy_Sought: New hearing with different decision-maker and proper interpretation
Legal_Standard_Applied: Right to adequate interpretation under Section 14, Charter
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness (implied by judicial review context)
Decision_Rationale: Inadequate interpretation undermined fairness and credibility assessment, requiring remittal
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (implied), Federal Court (judicial review)

Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's behavior caused confusion, not faulty translation
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution by police and militants in Punjab
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Viability of Internal Flight Alternative (IFA) in New Delhi
Proceeding_Type: Judicial review of refugee protection decision
Application_Error: Alleged procedural unfairness due to interpretation issues
Legal_Standard: Precision, continuity, competence, impartiality, and contemporaneousness in interpretation
No serious risk of persecution and reasonable relocation conditions for IFA
Application_Factor: Availability of safe relocation within India

Crime_Name: Violation of Charter Right to Language Interpretation
Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Legal_Provision_Involved: Section 14 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Grounds_for_Claim: Inaccurate, incomplete, and incompetent interpretation during hearing
Legal_Framework: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Decision_Outcome: Judicial review granted; new hearing ordered
Institutional_Action: Remanded to Refugee Protection Division for a new hearing
Credibility: Evidence from tape analysis and audit report confirmed deficiencies
Legal_Provision: Section 14, Charter of Rights and Freedoms
State_Protection_Adequacy: Found inadequate due to interpreter's inexperience and errors
Victim_Basis: Right to fair hearing with competent interpretation

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: subsection 29(2) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c. 27
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed his visitor visa and failed to attend initial proceedings; later attended with counsel.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged lack of notice and denial of interpreter rights
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of immigration officer to issue exclusion order
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Proof of visa overstay, attendance records, representation by counsel, language comprehension
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: None found – applicant understood English and was represented
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claim of lack of notice not supported by evidence
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Cancellation of removal order and procedural reconsideration
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No breach of procedural fairness; mandatory exclusion order under Regulation 228 due to overstay

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under subsection 29(2) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: subsection 29(2) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c. 27
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa, missed initial proceedings, later attended with counsel; claimed lack of notice, interpreter issues, and ignored H&C factors.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Claims of inadequate notice, lack of interpreter, and failure to consider H&C
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Scope of immigration officer’s duty in procedural fairness
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Record of non-attendance, counsel representation, demonstrated English comprehension, absence of H&C referral requirement
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: H&C claims not substantiated or required at exclusion stage
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant understood proceedings; interpreter not necessary
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Overturn exclusion order based on procedural unfairness
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Mandatory exclusion for inadmissibility under subsection 29(2)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No obligation to provide interpreter when comprehension evident; H&C considerations separate from exclusion orders

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with residency obligation under section 28
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: section 28 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c. 27
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visitor visa and did not fulfill residency obligations; submitted H&C application but excluded from IAD referral
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant – failed to meet residency obligation
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged failure to consider humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) factors
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority to issue exclusion without IAD referral when inadmissible solely for overstay
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Visa duration records, departure history, submission of H&C application
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: H&C factors not grounds to bypass mandatory exclusion under section 28
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No challenge to credibility; focus on legal applicability
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Exclusion order issued lawfully without IAD referral
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Set aside exclusion order and refer to IAD
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Procedural referral to Immigration Appeal Division
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Mandatory exclusion under IRPA when inadmissible solely for overstay
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Section 28 requires exclusion order without IAD referral if inadmissibility is based solely on overstay

Crimes.Crime_Name: Making false representations (regarding refugee claim withdrawal)
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration enforcement and deferral of removal
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Was the officer's decision to deny deferral of removal reasonable under IRPA?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s.48
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer assessed credibility of fraud allegations and hardship claims
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Alleged fraud, risks in Malaysia, children's best interests, psychological hardship
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA s.48 – Enforcement of removal orders
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Applicants claimed fraud and hardship as grounds for deferral
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: No exceptional circumstances such as risk of death or inhumane treatment found
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to administrative decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Limited discretion for deferral under IRPA s.48
Crimes.Application_Factor: Children's best interests, alleged fraud, country conditions in Malaysia
Crimes.Authority: Canada Border Services Agency (CBSA), Federal Court
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Allegations of misrepresentation regarding refugee claim withdrawal

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with removal order
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA s.48 – Duty to enforce removal orders promptly
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s.48
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants sought deferral due to fraud, risks in Malaysia, and children’s educational needs
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failure to comply with removal order despite enforcement
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged fraudulent activities impacting immigration status
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Request for deferral reviewed under administrative process
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Psychological hardship, police complaints, children's best interests, fraud allegations
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer evaluated credibility of claims for deferral
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Stay of removal based on humanitarian and personal circumstances
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Exceptional circumstances required for deferral under IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No risk of death, extreme sanction, or inhumane treatment established
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: CBSA enforcement officer, Federal Court on judicial review

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Victim of financial fraud impacting immigration proceedings
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether fraud and resulting hardship justify deferral of removal
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s.48
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Claims of fraud and financial loss considered but not sufficient for deferral
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to demonstrate exceptional circumstances
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Allegations of victimization by fraud assessed but not determinative
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Removal must proceed unless exceptional circumstances exist
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Hardship and risk upon return due to prior fraud victimization
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Application dismissed; no intervention by court
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Extent of financial loss, impact on family, safety concerns in Malaysia
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA framework for enforcement of removal orders
Crimes.Defendant_Response: N/A – Applicants were respondents seeking relief
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Financial records, police complaints, personal affidavits
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Deferral of removal on humanitarian grounds

Crimes.Violation_Type: Immigration violation - failure to comply with visa conditions
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 25(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant, a Grenadian citizen, overstayed her visa and applied for permanent residence based on domestic abuse and children's welfare
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Non-status immigrant, applicant for permanent residence
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to maintain legal residency status
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to conduct adequate humanitarian and compassionate grounds assessment
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Evidence of domestic abuse, children’s ties to Canada, risks in Grenada
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer did not fully analyze evidence regarding children's best interests
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; focus was on procedural inadequacy
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent residency on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review and remand for reconsideration
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations under s. 25(1)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Insufficient analysis of the best interests of the children affected
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration officer, later reviewed by Federal Court

Crimes.Crime_Name: Humanitarian and Compassionate Grounds Application Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration refusal on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the officer properly assessed the best interests of the child
Crimes.Governing_Law: Section 25(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review following application refusal and request for reconsideration
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Failure to consider severity of abuse in Grenada and best interests of Canadian-born child
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Application refused; reconsideration request dismissed as moot
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate compelling humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant's claims of abuse and risk to children were central but not adequately assessed
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Officers must meaningfully assess best interests of children under s. 25(1)
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Risk of harm to children if returned to Grenada, child's ties to Canada
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Original decision quashed; case remanded for reconsideration
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of domestic abuse, child's birth and upbringing in Canada, risks in country of origin
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Humanitarian and compassionate provisions in immigration law
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavits, medical records, police reports (implied)
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Reconsideration of application by a different officer
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 25(1), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Legal_Provision_Violated: s. 72 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Lin claimed refugee status due to fear of persecution for attending an underground Christian church in China.
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review application under s. 72 of the Act challenging the Board’s rejection of Lin’s refugee claim.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Inconsistencies in testimony, lack of documentary evidence
Credibility_Assessment: Board questioned credibility due to inconsistencies and lack of evidence; court found assessment reasonable.
Relief_Sought: Overturning of the Board's decision on judicial review
Decision_Rationale: The Board's decision was based on sufficient reasons including credibility concerns and lack of supporting documentation.

Crime_Name: Possession of cocaine for the purpose of trafficking

Violation_Type: Failure to provide adequate state protection assessment
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 101(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Application_Facts: Applicant fled Saint Lucia due to domestic abuse and sought asylum in Canada; challenged negative PRRA decision based on inadequate state protection assessment
Residency_Compliance: Compliant with Canadian immigration procedures at time of application
Procedural_Issue: PRRA Officer treated failure to seek state protection as fatal, relied on non-police agencies for protection, failed to properly consider country condition evidence
Evidence_Used: Country condition reports on Saint Lucia, applicant's testimony on domestic abuse
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer disregarded relevant country condition evidence
Outcome: Judicial review granted; decision found unreasonable
Relief_Sought: Stay of removal, reevaluation of PRRA
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of PRRA by a different officer
Decision_Rationale: Officer's conclusion was not justified, transparent, or intelligible; fell outside acceptable range of outcomes due to errors in assessing state protection
Authority_Responsible: PRRA Officer, Federal Court (on judicial review)

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration status and disclosure obligation
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether failure to disclose change in marital status constitutes misrepresentation under s. 27(1)(e)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claim of ignorance rejected
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Signed immigration documents declaring accuracy of information
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Failure to update marital status before entry
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Duty to disclose material facts regardless of intent
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Misrepresentation includes non-disclosure of material facts
Crimes.Document_Fraud: False declaration through omission in official forms

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant married before landing but did not report it
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Applicant seeking entry as single individual
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to comply with disclosure requirements
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of proof of notification of marital change
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Ignorance not accepted as defense
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Failure to disclose material fact constitutes misrepresentation regardless of intent

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 183 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Mr. Sodhi overstayed his visa, left Canada, and reapplied for a student visa; evidence showed attendance at Algonquin College after departure date.
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Not applicable – decision based on non-compliance, not false information
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged lack of procedural fairness in refusal
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal court jurisdiction over immigration decisions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No proof of studies in India during gap period
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer questioned credibility due to academic attendance in Canada post-departure
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Certification of general importance and quashing of refusal
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of visa officer’s decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer reasonably concluded re-entry without authorization based on applicant-provided evidence

Crimes.Crime_Name: Re-entering Canada without authorization under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration admissibility
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether Mr. Sodhi re-entered Canada illegally after deportation
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Transcripts and diploma indicated Canadian study post-2005 without valid status
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate lawful entry and compliance
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Lack of documentation supporting studies in India or lawful re-entry
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Applicants must prove they entered Canada legally and will comply with visa terms
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged error in factual findings and procedural unfairness
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA sections related to admissibility and visa issuance
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Visa officer relied on applicant-submitted documents
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence (transcripts, diploma)

Crimes.Application_Facts: Mr. Sodhi did not provide evidence of lawful status or explain presence in Canada after departure
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Deported individual reapplying for student visa
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: History of non-compliance with immigration status
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Implied omission of whereabouts and re-entry details
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Allegation that officer failed to give chance to respond to adverse inference
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Student transcripts, diploma, absence of Indian study records
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No documentation proving legal stay outside Canada or authorized re-entry
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer found applicant's explanation insufficient
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Visa refused due to credibility and compliance concerns
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: All evidence was provided by applicant; no procedural unfairness found

Legal_Provision_Violated: s. 19(1)(a)(ii) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Principal claimant diagnosed with aortic valvular disease; potential for excessive demand on health services due to long-term medical needs
Procedural_Issue: IAD questioned medical opinion without contradictory evidence; misinterpreted 'long term' and 'short term' prognosis
Jurisdictional_Issue: Whether IAD acted within its jurisdiction in assessing medical opinion
Evidentiary_Deficiency: IAD found medical opinion insufficient and vague; court found no manifest unreasonableness
Credibility_Assessment: IAD questioned reliability of Dr. Sorokin's prognosis without expert contradiction
Decision_Outcome: IAD initially allowed appeal; decision set aside on judicial review
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; IAD decision overturned
Relief_Sought: Sponsor sought allowance of appeal against medical inadmissibility determination
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard; whether medical opinion is manifestly unreasonable
Decision_Rationale: IAD erred by requiring undue specificity and second-guessing medical opinion without contradictory evidence

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee status due to persecution as a lesbian in Iran
Procedural_Issue: Board made speculative plausibility findings without supporting evidence
Dismissed corroborative evidence without proper justification
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of corroborating evidence considered without justification
Credibility_Assessment: Maldonado presumption of truthfulness not properly applied
Implausibility findings not rebutted with evidence
Decision_Rationale: Board erred in making unsupported plausibility determinations and dismissing evidence without justification

Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical presence requirement
Application_Facts: El-Khader was physically present for 925 days out of the required 1,095 days within four years preceding application
Procedural_Issue: Appeal from Citizenship Judge's decision to Federal Court; argument over use of quantitative vs. qualitative test
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of sufficient documented residency to meet statutory threshold
Relief_Sought: Overturn Citizenship Judge's decision and grant citizenship
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of Citizenship Judge's interpretation and application of residency requirement
Decision_Rationale: Citizenship Judge reasonably applied the quantitative physical presence test as per Pourghasemi; consistent with statutory interpretation principles

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants overstayed their visas after failed refugee claims and applied for humanitarian and compassionate grounds to remain.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged lack of opportunity to update information, use of extrinsic evidence, bias
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient demonstration of unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate hardship
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permission to remain in Canada on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Quashing of officer's decision via judicial review
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer considered all relevant factors including hardship; no procedural unfairness or legal error found

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Humanitarian and compassionate application denial
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Fairness, bias, legal test application, reasonableness
Crimes.Application_Error: Alleged procedural unfairness and misapplication of legal test
Crimes.Application_Factor: Length of stay, family ties, risk upon return

Crimes.Crime_Name: Illegal entry into the United States
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Humanitarian and compassionate application denial
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Fairness, bias, correct legal test, reasonableness
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds following illegal U.S. stay and failed refugee claim
Crimes.Application_Error: Alleged failure to apply proper legal test and procedural unfairness
Crimes.Application_Factor: Prior illegal residence in U.S., failed refugee claim, establishment in Canada

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the Board err in rejecting the applicants' claim based on identity?
Crimes.Outcome: Board's decision overturned, case sent back for reassessment
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Minor inconsistencies in testimony were deemed significant by the Board
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimonial evidence without supporting documents
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Failure to establish identity due to lack of documentation
Crimes.Application_Error: Overly strict assessment of minor inconsistencies
Crimes.Application_Factor: Lack of identity documents and reliance on oral testimony
Crimes.Authority: Federal Court under IRPA and Federal Courts Act

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to provide acceptable identity documentation
Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to meet documentary requirements under immigration law
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants provided no documents, relied on testimonial evidence
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Board rejected claim due to insufficient proof of identity
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Minor inconsistencies affected credibility
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Acceptance of claim based on testimonial evidence
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Re-determination by a different Board member
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonable justification for lack of documents under s.106

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Credibility assessment based on testimonial inconsistencies
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the Board err in rejecting the applicants' identity based on minor inconsistencies in testimonial evidence?
Crimes.Outcome: Board's decision overturned, case referred for reassessment
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Minor inconsistencies in testimony (e.g., house color, material) deemed overly significant despite alignment in key areas
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimonial evidence; no official documents provided
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Lack of Somali identity documents and use of fraudulent German passports
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Use of fraudulent passports and minor testimonial discrepancies
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review under IRPA s.72 and Federal Courts Act s.18.1
Crimes.Application_Error: Overly microscopic examination of minor inconsistencies
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Possibility of translation issues affecting testimony
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonable possibility of truth in testimonial evidence when documents are unavailable
Crimes.Application_Factor: Reliance on oral testimony due to lack of documentation
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Remanded for re-determination by a different Board member
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Use of fraudulent German passports to enter Canada

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to provide necessaries of life (negligence claim dismissed)
Application_Facts: Inmate injured during an assault and claimed negligence due to delayed medical attention.
Procedural_Issue: Trial focused on whether the defendant breached duty of care; causation deferred to second phase.
Decision_Outcome: Action dismissed with costs to the defendant.
Outcome: No breach of duty of care found.
Legal_Standard_Applied: The Crown is vicariously liable for negligence if an officer, acting within employment scope, fails to meet the standard of care expected of a reasonable person.
Decision_Rationale: No evidence that corrections officers acted below the standard of care. The plaintiff’s condition was not visibly obvious, and multiple checks were conducted without signs of distress.

Application_Facts: Inmate assault leading to Bastarache's injury and subsequent negligence claim against prison staff.
Procedural_Issue: Trial focused on whether prison staff breached duty of care; bifurcated trial separated liability and damages.
Decision_Outcome: Action dismissed with costs to defendant.
Outcome: No breach of duty of care occurred.
Legal_Standard_Applied: Prison authorities owe a duty of care to inmates, requiring reasonable measures to ensure their health and safety.
Decision_Rationale: Bastarache was injured but concealed it, locking his cell. Officers conducted regular checks without noticing distress. No evidence shows officers acted below the standard of care.

Decision_Outcome: Action dismissed with costs fixed at $1,500 payable by plaintiff to defendant.
Criminal_Activity: Inmate assault leading to severe injury and subsequent negligence claim against prison officials.
Outcome: No breach of duty occurred as officers acted reasonably given the circumstances.
Basis_for_Decision: Bastarache was injured but concealed it, locking his cell after refusing medical attention. Officers conducted regular checks without noticing issues. Blanchard’s claim of alerting officers was deemed unreliable.
Legal_Framework: Prison authorities owe a duty of care to inmates, requiring reasonable measures to ensure health and safety. Liability arises if actions fall below the standard of a reasonably prudent person.

Credibility_Assessment: Blanchard’s claim of alerting officers was deemed unreliable.
Legal_Provision: Prison authorities owe a duty of care to inmates, requiring reasonable measures to ensure health and safety. Liability arises if acts or omissions fall below the standard of a reasonably prudent person.

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Application denial based on truthfulness
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether failure to disclose a provisionally dismissed charge constitutes untruthful answer under s. 16
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, sections 16 and 40
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer rejected applicant's explanations without proper basis
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Applicant's visa application, explanation of charge status, Philippine law on provisional dismissal
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Omission of provisionally dismissed criminal charge
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Provisional dismissal under Philippine law and lack of officer inquiry
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to disclose charge deemed untruthful
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Applicant's explanation and foreign legal context of provisional dismissal
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Standard of reasonableness in administrative decision-making
Crimes.Application_Factor: Nature of criminal charge and its legal effect abroad
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Order for reconsideration with prioritized processing

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 16 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant claimed no outstanding charges despite provisionally dismissed charge
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Officer failed to investigate legal nature of dismissal or consider explanations
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Application of s. 16 without invoking s. 40
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of inquiry into foreign legal framework
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's explanations dismissed without justification
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Judicial review allowed; case remitted for reconsideration
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Denial under s. 16 was inappropriate without full factual inquiry
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration officer, subject to court oversight

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to maintain temporary resident status
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA and IRPR - Failure to meet conditions for temporary residency or restoration
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants entered Canada to care for a sick relative; after her death, they applied for permanent residency and sought restoration of visitor status.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Foreign nationals applying for permanent residency
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to expired status, but applied for restoration
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Officer failed to consider new temporary purpose for stay
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Evidence of application for permanent residency, intent to remain temporarily during processing
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer ignored evidence of new temporary purpose
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Remission for redetermination by a different officer
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Requirement of temporary purpose under IRPA/IRPR
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer erred by focusing solely on original purpose and not considering ongoing temporary purpose during PR application

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with conditions of temporary resident status
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration status and compliance with conditions
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Officer properly assessed the existence of a temporary purpose for stay
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicants provided evidence of pending permanent residency application as basis for continued stay
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Denial of restoration of temporary resident status
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to demonstrate intent to leave at end of authorized stay
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicants' stated intention to await permanent residency processing
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Intent to apply for permanent residency does not preclude temporary resident status if there is a genuine temporary purpose
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Officer failed to consider updated circumstances and applicable legal provisions
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Pending sponsorship application, duration of processing, original entry purpose
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA and IRPR provisions on temporary residence and restoration
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Officer emphasized original purpose being fulfilled and length of processing time
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of application, affidavits, immigration records
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Remission for reconsideration by a different officer
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 18(1) IRPA – Temporary Resident Status; Section 180 IRPR – Restoration of status

Application_Facts: The PRRA Officer assessed specific risks to the applicant and state protection in Sri Lanka based on evidence.
Procedural_Issue: The applicant challenged a negative PRRA decision, arguing improper risk assessment and incorrect findings on state protection.
Evidence_Used: Evidence regarding risk and state protection in Sri Lanka was considered by the PRRA Officer.
Decision_Outcome: The court found no legal error or insufficient evidence in the PRRA decision.
Outcome: The motion for a stay is dismissed; removal order proceeds.
Remedy_Sought: Suspension of removal based on alleged errors in PRRA decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious issues to be tried, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Decision_Rationale: No legal error or factual insufficiency found in PRRA officer's assessment of risk and state protection.

Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical presence requirement
Legal_Provision_Violated: Residency requirement under the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed residency in Canada but failed to provide sufficient evidence for days physically present; relevant expired passport was destroyed without justification; other documents inconclusive
Procedural_Issue: Destruction of key evidence (expired passport) without adequate justification
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's evidence deemed insufficient; uncertainty about claimed residency days
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of Citizenship Judge's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: 1095 days of physical presence within four years
three tests: strict day-counting, qualitative assessment, centralization of mode of existence
Decision_Rationale: Citizenship Judge correctly applied the physical presence test and reasonably concluded that the applicant did not meet the residency requirement due to lack of credible evidence

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the PRRA officer err in concluding that state protection was available to the applicant in Russia?
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: The officer found insufficient evidence to support the applicant's claim of threat from her ex-boyfriend.
Evidence_Type: Claim of fear due to ex-boyfriend
PRRA officer's assessment of state protection
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act – burden to rebut presumption of state protection
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of harm from ex-boyfriend upon return to Russia
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Adequate state protection exists in Russia
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Clear and convincing evidence required to rebut presumption of state protection
Crimes.Application_Factor: Applicant's removal after visa expiration and fear-based PRRA application

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act – residency compliance
Crimes.Application_Facts: Ms. Kozyreva overstayed her visa and applied for PRRA due to fear of ex-boyfriend
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Temporary resident who became undocumented after visa expiry
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Filing of PRRA application following visa overstay
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient objective evidence to support ongoing threat or lack of state protection
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer found claim not sufficiently supported by evidence
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent residence on humanitarian grounds via PRRA
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Stay of removal based on risk in country of origin
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Clear evidence required to rebut presumption of state protection
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: State protection in Russia deemed adequate; no compelling reason not to avail it

Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Applicant entered new relationship; improvements in Russian law enforcement
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: PRRA officer found threat not ongoing
Evidence_Type: Lack of police reports or documentation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claim not supported by sufficient credible evidence
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act – risk and protection assessment

Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Applicant in new relationship; availability of legal protections in Russia
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient evidence to prove lack of state protection
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claim not sufficiently credible or supported
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act – gender-based persecution analysis

Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: New relationship; existence of legal remedies in Russia
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient evidence of actual or threatened assault
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claim not backed by objective evidence
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act – personal risk and protection availability

Legal_Provision_Violated: Sections 3 and 39 of the Pension Act
Application_Facts: Delayed cancer diagnosis during military service leading to extensive surgery and disability; Drs. Hurley and Jaeger provided credible opinions on delayed diagnosis; VRAB dismissed claim citing lack of evidence of medical mismanagement
Procedural_Issue: VRAB failed to reverse the onus of proof; misconstrued medical evidence
Evidence_Used: Medical opinions from Drs. Hurley and Jaeger indicating delayed cancer diagnosis
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of sufficient evidence of medical mismanagement as cited by VRAB
Credibility_Assessment: Drs. Hurley and Jaeger's opinions deemed credible by the court
Decision_Outcome: VRAB's decision found perverse due to ignored or misconstrued evidence
Outcome: VRAB's decision overturned; new hearing ordered
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of VRAB's denial of disability pension
Remedy_Sought: New hearing with a different VRAB panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Any doubt should be resolved in favor of the applicant under the Pension Act
Decision_Rationale: Court found the VRAB's decision unreasonable due to failure to properly assess credible medical evidence and misapplication of burden of proof

Dispute_Type: Civil dispute over intellectual property rights
Legal_Issue: Whether Euro Excellence is liable for damages and profits due to copyright infringement of Kraft Canada's artistic works on chocolate bar wrappers
Procedural_Stage: Initial trial, appeal, remand for redetermination of damages, motions regarding new evidence, final determination
Evidence_Assessment: Gross sales of $2.8 million; lack of cost evidence from Euro Excellence; Kraft's proposed 10-25% of gross sales as reasonable
Decision_Outcome: Euro Excellence must pay $300,000 in damages plus interest and one set of costs
Burden_of_Proof: On Kraft Canada to establish infringement and quantify damages/profits
Credibility_Factor: Court found Kraft's proposed range reasonable despite lack of precise evidence
Legal_Rule: Under Section 35(1) of the Copyright Act, infringer is liable for owner's damages and portion of profits not accounted for in damages
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness of damages assessment on remand
Grounds_for_Claim: Unauthorized sale of products with copyrighted chocolate bar wrappers
Key_Evidence_Considered: Gross sales figures, absence of cost documentation from defendant, plaintiff's profit margin proposal
Legal_Framework: Canadian Copyright Act, civil litigation procedures
Defendant_Response: Did not provide evidence of costs incurred
Evidence_Type: Financial records, expert or industry practice on profit margins
Outcome: $300,000 in damages, interest, and one set of costs awarded to Kraft Canada
Authority: Federal Court of Appeal, Federal Court

Crimes.Crime_Name: Engagement in criminal activity planned and organized by a number of persons acting in concert
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration inadmissibility based on alleged gang involvement
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether Mr. Mendoza is inadmissible under IRPA for membership in a criminal organization
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Mr. Mendoza admitted involvement with Mara Salvatrucha, including taxing people and attending meetings; IAD found reasonable grounds to believe membership despite coercion claims
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the Minister to establish inadmissibility on balance of probabilities
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Claim of coercion considered but not accepted due to knowledge of group's violent activities
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Membership in an organization believed to engage in planned criminal activity leads to inadmissibility under IRPA s.37(1)(a)
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Claimed coercion into joining Mara Salvatrucha

Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Fair hearing before IAD after Minister’s appeal
Crimes.Criminal_Activity: Mara Salvatrucha engaged in violent and coercive activities including extortion
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: Admitted participation in MS-13 activities such as taxing bus passengers
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Association with transnational criminal gang linked to violence and intimidation
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Reasonable grounds to believe membership in criminal organization

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Association with violent criminal organization (Mara Salvatrucha)
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Claim of coercion into joining the group
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High – linked to organized violence and intimidation
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk due to gang affiliation and potential for re-engagement
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Potential for future criminal behavior due to ongoing ties or influence
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Not applicable – general pattern of coercion and control
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient based on admissions and context
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Partially credible – coercion claim not fully accepted
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Knowledge of violent acts undermines claim of complete lack of agency
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: N/A – immigration consequence rather than criminal sentencing

Crime_Name: Failing to comply with appearance orders
Legal_Rule: Court may hear moot case if it affects rights or involves public importance, adversarial context, or judicial economy
Grounds_for_Claim: Minister sought guidance on cross-examination rights

Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Refusal to allow cross-examination of bondsperson
Basis_for_Decision: Mootness, lack of adversarial input, prior rulings
Legal_Framework: Federal Court discretion in moot cases

Dispute_Type: Judicial review of detention hearing procedure
Legal_Issue: Cross-examination rights in immigration detention review
Governing_Law: Federal Court rules on mootness and procedural fairness
Legal_Rule: Moot cases require adversarial context, public importance, or judicial economy
Grounds_for_Claim: Public importance and recurrence of issue

Violation_Type: Failure to comply with conditions of release pending deportation
Procedural_Issue: Denial of cross-examination at detention review
Decision_Rationale: Issue previously decided, no adversarial context

Dispute_Type: Judicial review of procedural decision in immigration hearing
Legal_Issue: Right to cross-examine bondsperson in detention review
Legal_Rule: Supreme Court two-step test for mootness
Grounds_for_Claim: Public importance and recurring nature of issue

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of RPD decision on refugee claim
Governing_Law: UN Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; RPD decision upheld
Credibility_Assessment: Family's experiences analyzed; some incidents deemed non-discriminatory
Evidence_Type: Evidence of discrimination, state protection measures, personal testimony
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution based on Roma descent
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of systemic racial discrimination in Hungary; state efforts to improve Roma conditions
Assessment_Standard: Serious, sustained, or systematic mistreatment due to a Convention ground
Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada

Dispute_Type: Discovery dispute in patent infringement case
Legal_Issue: Relevance and scope of discovery questions under Federal Court Rules
Evidence_Assessment: Questions related to inducement, commercial success, and hypothetical scenarios assessed for relevance and speculation
Decision_Outcome: Most decisions upheld; two hypothetical questions (3324, 3326) excluded; Gulf States/Deco category ordered to be answered
Burden_of_Proof: On party resisting discovery to show irrelevance or undue burden
Legal_Rule: Rule 458(1): Questions must relate to unadmitted allegations of fact or persons with relevant knowledge
Standard_of_Review: Deferential, unless clearly wrong or vital to final issues
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged patent infringement involving paper plates
Outcome_on_Merits: Partial allowance of appeal; some questions required answers
Key_Evidence_Considered: Discovery questions on inducement, commercial success, hypothetical market behavior
Defendant_Response: Objections to certain discovery questions as irrelevant or speculative
Remedy_Requested: Compel answers to specific discovery questions

Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses

Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses

Legal_Issue: Whether the Refugee Protection Division erred in dismissing the applicant's refugee claim based on religious persecution and forced sterilization risks
Governing_Law: Under Canadian immigration law, a valid refugee claim requires proof of persecution risk
Outcome: The Board erred by not addressing whether restrictions on the applicant's faith practice could amount to persecution. The decision is set aside for reconsideration
Evidence_Type: Assumption that applicant would join a safe church in Fujian
Failure to assess specific situation or consider restrictions on faith practice
Basis_of_Claim: Risks related to China's One Child Policy
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Risk of persecution due to religious practice and forced sterilization
Application_Error: Failure to assess applicant's specific circumstances and potential persecution based on religious practice
Evidence_Ignored: Specific restrictions on applicant's ability to practice religion freely
Legal_Standard: Proof of risk of persecution under Canadian immigration law
Application_Factor: Membership in a particular social group
Decision_Outcome: Claim remitted for re-determination by a different panel

Legal_Provision: Section 18.2 of the Federal Court Act
Section 18.2 of the Federal Court Act
Section 18.2 of the Federal Court Act
Section 18.2 of the Federal Court Act
Assessment_Standard: Tri-partite test: serious issue, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Decision_Outcome: Conditional stay until judicial review concludes

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Legal_Provision_Involved: paragraph 72(2)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Decision_Outcome: Statute-barred due to failure to exhaust appeal rights

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to exhaust appeal rights under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Violation_Type: Failure to exhaust statutory appeal rights
Application_Facts: Applicant found inadmissible for serious criminality, ordered deported, did not appeal to IAD before seeking judicial review
Procedural_Issue: Attempt to bypass mandatory IAD appeal process
Outcome: Applicant must first appeal to IAD
Decision_Rationale: Section 72(2)(a) bars judicial review until all appeals are exhausted

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of immigration inadmissibility assessment
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of CBSA's preliminary assessment of inadmissibility on security grounds
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: CBSA failed to assess Galloway's intent behind aid delivery
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Humanitarian nature of aid, lack of intent to support terrorism
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged support for Hamas through humanitarian aid
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of analysis of donor's purpose or intent
Crimes.Application_Error: Overreach in interpreting facts and law without sufficient basis
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Intent and actual use of humanitarian aid
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonable grounds to believe, more than suspicion but less than balance of probabilities
Crimes.Application_Factor: Delivery of aid to Gaza under Hamas control
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Application dismissed due to absence of final reviewable decision

Crimes.Crime_Name: Providing material support to a terrorist organization
Crimes.National_Security_Element: Alleged support to Hamas, a listed terrorist entity
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Potential enhancement of terrorist activities through material support
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: CBSA's determination of risk based on aid delivery
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Provision of cash and goods to area controlled by terrorist organization
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Voluntary delivery of humanitarian aid (cash and goods)
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Acknowledged delivery of aid, denied terrorist intent
Crimes.Leadership_Role: No evidence of leadership or operational role
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Evidence showed aid was humanitarian and not diverted to terrorism
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Absence of intent to further terrorist objectives
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentation of humanitarian purpose, public statements, aid distribution records
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Galloway's intent assessed as humanitarian, not supportive of terrorism
Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Transparency of aid mission, public nature of delivery
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of inadmissibility assessment
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Attempted exclusion from Canada, blocked speaking tour

Crimes.National_Security_Element: Allegation of membership in Hamas due to aid delivery
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: CBSA’s belief that Galloway may be complicit via support
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Association with a listed terrorist entity despite humanitarian intent
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Delivery of humanitarian aid through Hamas channels
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Acknowledged involvement in aid delivery only
Crimes.Leadership_Role: No indication of leadership or organizational role
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Supporting evidence demonstrated purely humanitarian objectives
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: No evidence of intent to engage in terrorism or organizational membership
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Publicly documented aid mission, recipient use of supplies
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credible assertion of humanitarian purpose
Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Consistent public statements, transparency of actions
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of preliminary inadmissibility finding
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Prevention of entry into Canada for speaking tour

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration application refusal
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Adequacy of reasons for finding misrepresentation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer did not provide sufficient analysis of credibility
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Employment history documentation
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged misrepresentation in employment details on PR application
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of specific inconsistencies identified by Officer
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to disclose or falsify material facts
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Evidence provided by applicant in response to procedural fairness letter

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration inadmissibility determination
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Sufficiency of reasons for inadmissibility finding
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No clear assessment of applicant's credibility provided
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Employment history records and application materials
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged false statements regarding employment history
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to specify nature and extent of misrepresentation
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Misrepresentation of material fact that could lead to error
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision set aside, remanded to new Officer

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Procedural fairness in PRRA assessment
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the PRRA officer breached principles of fairness by not updating the application after a two-year delay
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, section 113(a)
Crimes.Outcome: No breach of procedural fairness occurred; PRRA decision stands
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Alleged new risk was deemed implausible given prior RPD findings
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Lack of new or updated evidence from applicant
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 113(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Claim of increased personal risk upon return to home country
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Applicant's failure to provide updated information during the delay
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to update application with new circumstances
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None — no new evidence was submitted
Crimes.Legal_Standard: PRRA officers must assess new evidence but are not required to solicit updates
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: PRRA application rejected due to lack of new evidence

Crimes.Violation_Type: Remaining in Canada beyond authorized period
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 113(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Ms. Tovar remained in Canada after her visa expired while pursuing protection claims
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Not applicable — violation based on status, not false statements
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of PRRA decision and removal order
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over immigration decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: PRRA application, lack of updated submissions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to provide new evidence supporting continued stay
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Increased risk claim unsubstantiated
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal based on PRRA application
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Certification of a question for appeal
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness for PRRA, correctness for jurisdictional issues
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No procedural unfairness; applicant had opportunity to update but did not

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with removal order
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 44 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Ms. Tovar failed to depart Canada after final removal order was issued
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged oral deferral request not documented or acknowledged
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court review of removal process
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Removal interview records, absence of written deferral request
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No proof of formal deferral request
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claim of oral deferral request not accepted
Crimes.Outcome: Removal order remains valid and enforceable
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Set aside removal order or defer removal
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No duty to defer without clear request or practical impediment

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Suspected fraudulent marriage for immigration benefit
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether procedural fairness was violated in assessing credibility of relationship
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, sections 96 and 97
Crimes.Outcome: PRRA decision upheld; no procedural breach found
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Relationship claims lacked corroboration and consistency
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Lack of updated documentation or communication records
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution upon return due to changed personal circumstances
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to provide new evidence supporting genuine relationship
Crimes.Application_Error: Did not disclose or substantiate marital status changes
Crimes.Legal_Standard: PRRA officers assess risk based on submitted evidence
Crimes.Application_Factor: History of denied refugee claim and lack of cooperation
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Suspicion of sham marriage not proven but contributed to credibility concerns

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Alleged breach of procedural fairness in PRRA and removal processes
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether PRRA and removal officers respected natural justice
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, principles of procedural fairness
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Officer relied on existing record; no duty to seek new evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Inconsistent claims and lack of follow-up
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Officers must act fairly but are not required to prompt applicants for updates
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Two-year delay, alleged oral deferral request
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Absence of updated submissions or formal deferral request
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Administrative law principles applied to immigration decisions
Crimes.Defendant_Response: CBSA and IRCC maintained decisions were procedurally fair
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Written PRRA application, removal interview notes
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 113(a), IRPA; common law procedural fairness

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee status exclusion
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged complicity in MQM's crimes against humanity
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Immigration and Refugee Board review and judicial review
Crimes.Government_Body_or_Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Assessed as not entitled to protection due to complicity
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Membership and leadership in a violent organization
Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: Not applicable – excluded under international law

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Complicity in murder as part of crimes against humanity
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Leadership role, prolonged membership, fundraising for violent organization
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Denial of knowledge (rejected as not credible)
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Active involvement with MQM for 7 years
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk of complicity in serious crimes
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Civilians or political opponents (implied by MQM's pattern)
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient – based on organizational records and context
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, testimony, public reports
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Mr. Ali’s denial not credible
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: Not applicable – immigration exclusion instead of criminal sentencing

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee status exclusion
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged complicity in MQM's torture practices
Crimes.Government_Body_or_Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Not entitled to protection due to complicity
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Leadership and sustained involvement in MQM
Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: Inadequate due to exclusion under international law
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Systematic human rights abuse through organizational support

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Extortion (bhatta collection) as part of organized violence
Crimes.Victim_Status: Civilians or business owners targeted for forced donations
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Use of coercion, integration into broader campaign of violence
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Seven-year active membership including financial support
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High – part of systematic extortion network
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High – ongoing support to criminal enterprise
Crimes.Risk_Type: Association with organized crime and terrorism-linked group
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Supporting violent objectives through financial means
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient – documented patterns and role in fundraising
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimony, organizational documentation, country condition reports
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's denial not credible
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: Not applicable – administrative exclusion from refugee status

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility on security grounds under paragraph 34(1)(f) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of immigration inadmissibility decision
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in concluding that MQM is an organization engaging in terrorism
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), paragraph 34(1)(f)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Documentary evidence showing intimidation, torture, assassinations, and bomb attacks targeting civilians
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Board found sources credible despite claims of unreliability
Crimes.Legal_Rule: A person is inadmissible if they are a member of an organization reasonably believed to engage in terrorism
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Challenged credibility of evidence and sufficiency of proof regarding MQM's terrorist activities
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review to overturn inadmissibility finding
Crimes.Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board; Federal Court

Crimes.Crime_Name: Being a member of an organization that there are reasonable grounds to believe engages in terrorism
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Risk posed by association with alleged terrorist organization
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: MQM's involvement in violent acts against civilians
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Membership in organization linked to terrorism
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Documentary evidence deemed credible by the Board
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Sufficiency and reliability of evidence linking MQM to terrorism
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board found evidence credible and compelling
Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Consistency and detail of reports on MQM's activities
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Cited: Paragraph 34(1)(c) – engaging in terrorism; paragraph 34(1)(f) – membership in such organization
Crimes.Governing_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, section 34
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of inadmissibility based on organizational affiliation
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Inadmissibility to Canada on security grounds

Legal_Issue: Whether Procter & Gamble is entitled to an interlocutory injunction for alleged patent infringement
Evidence_Assessment: Affidavits from experts, lack of product sample, cross-examinations
Burden_of_Proof: Plaintiff must show: serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Credibility_Factor: Plaintiff established a prima facie case; defendant failed to refute evidence convincingly
Legal_Rule: Three-part test for interlocutory injunction: (a) serious issue to be tried, (b) irreparable harm, (c) balance of convenience favors plaintiff
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged infringement of patent by Colgate's Ultra Fleecy product prior to patent expiry
Outcome_on_Merits: Not determined; injunction granted pending trial or expiration
Key_Evidence_Considered: Expert affidavits, market launch plans, patent claims
Legal_Framework: Canadian patent law and equitable principles for injunctive relief
Defendant_Response: Denied infringement; argued lack of evidence and no demonstrated harm
Remedy_Requested: Interlocutory injunction to prevent sale of Ultra Fleecy
Outcome: Injunction granted; Colgate prohibited from selling Ultra Fleecy until patent expired
Legal_Provision: Interlocutory injunction provisions under Canadian equity and patent law
Authority: Canadian court with jurisdiction over intellectual property disputes

Legal_Issue: Does Richardson International Ltd. have a valid maritime lien on the vessel 'Mys Chikhacheva' under U.S. law?
Evidence_Assessment: Expert testimonies on Russian, Cypriot, and U.S. maritime laws
Decision_Outcome: Judgment granted to Richardson for $336,969.84 with pre-judgment interest and costs
Burden_of_Proof: Supplier of necessaries must establish valid provision of services and applicable maritime lien under governing law
Credibility_Factor: Authorization by bareboat charterer Starodubskoe; explicit choice of U.S. law in contracts
Legal_Rule: Under U.S. maritime law, a supplier of necessaries to a vessel is entitled to a maritime lien unless explicitly waived
Standard_of_Review: Application of U.S. maritime law based on contractual choice of law
Grounds_for_Claim: Provision of fuel, provisions, and technician services to the vessel 'Mys Chikhacheva' by Richardson International Ltd.
Outcome_on_Merits: Richardson has a valid maritime lien on the 'Mys Chikhacheva' for $336,969.84 under U.S. maritime law
Key_Evidence_Considered: Contracts between Richardson and Starodubskoe, ownership claims by Bering, role of Starodubskoe as bareboat charterer
Legal_Framework: U.S. maritime law, principles of maritime liens, contract law
Defendant_Response: Bering's claim of ownership and challenge to validity of lien
Remedy_Requested: Maritime lien enforcement for $336,969.84, pre-judgment interest, and costs
Outcome: Judgment in favor of Richardson International Ltd.
Legal_Provision: U.S. maritime lien statute for necessaries

Legal_Issue: Whether the applicants' right to a fair hearing, specifically their right to an interpreter, met procedural fairness standards
Governing_Law: Section 14 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Evidence_Assessment: Post-hearing analysis revealed significant interpretation errors that altered the applicants' statements
Decision_Outcome: Federal Court allowed the judicial review; case remanded for rehearing with a qualified interpreter
Credibility_Factor: Adverse credibility findings due to poor interpretation affecting testimony
Legal_Rule: Section 14 guarantees the right to an interpreter; interpretation must be continuous, precise, competent, impartial, and contemporaneous
Grounds_for_Claim: Infringement of the right to a fair hearing due to inadequate interpretation services
Outcome_on_Merits: Applicants' rights were found to be infringed
Key_Evidence_Considered: Applicants' rudimentary French knowledge, request for interpreter, discrepancies in interpretation during hearing, post-hearing analysis of interpretation errors
Legal_Framework: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review, rehearing with qualified interpreter
Outcome: Case remanded to a differently constituted panel for redetermination with proper interpretation
Legal_Provision: Section 14 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms

Legal_Issue: Was the RPD's assessment of the applicant's credibility and evidence reasonable?
Credibility_Assessment: RPD questioned credibility due to lack of corroborative evidence, inconsistencies in testimony, and re-availment of state protection in Turkey
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution as a Kurd in Turkey
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Credibility, lack of evidence, re-availment of state protection
Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard requiring deference to factual and mixed fact-law determinations
Application_Factor: Credibility, consistency, availability of state protection
Decision_Outcome: RPD's decision upheld; refugee claim dismissed
